mainmatter.p: Some sources require a bicomplex to have anti-commuting squares. In this way, the total complex has the simpler differential \partial = d + \delta∂=d+δ\partial = d + \delta∂=d+δ. These two definitions are convertible by flipping the signs of the horizontal boundary maps in every other row.

A bicomplex is a chain complex of chain complexes. More specifically, we have a grid of objects A_{m, n}Am,nA_{m, n}Am,n​, vertical maps d : A_{m, n} \to A_{m, n-1}d:Am,n→Am,n−1d : A_{m, n} \to A_{m, n-1}d:Am,n​→Am,n−1​ and horizontal maps \delta : A_{m, n} \to A_{m-1, n}δ:Am,n→Am−1,n\delta : A_{m, n} \to A_{m-1, n}δ:Am,n​→Am−1,n​. Every square in the grid commutes, and d^2 = \delta ^2 = 0d2=δ2=0d^2 = \delta ^2 = 0d2=δ2=0.

Each column A_{m, \bullet }Am,∙A_{m, \bullet }Am,∙​ in the bicomplex is a chain complex, and \deltaδ\deltaδ are chain maps between the column complexes. Similarly, each row forms a chain complex, and dddd are chain maps between the row complexes.

Given a bicomplex C_{ \bullet , \bullet }C∙,∙C_{ \bullet , \bullet }C∙,∙​, we can collapse it into a chain complex in two ways. In either way, C_{p, q}Cp,qC_{p, q}Cp,q​ is contained in the total complex at degree (m+n)(m+n)(m+n)(m+n). We can use the direct sum to combine them: \operatorname {Tot} ^ \oplus (C)_n = \bigoplus _{n = p+q} C_{p, q},Tot⁡⊕(C)n=⨁n=p+qCp,q,\operatorname {Tot} ^ \oplus (C)_n = \bigoplus _{n = p+q} C_{p, q},Tot⊕(C)n​=n=p+q⨁​Cp,q​, or the direct product: \operatorname {Tot} ^ \Pi (C)_n = \prod _{n=p+q} C_{p,q}.Tot⁡Π(C)n=∏n=p+qCp,q.\operatorname {Tot} ^ \Pi (C)_n = \prod _{n=p+q} C_{p,q}.TotΠ(C)n​=n=p+q∏​Cp,q​.

The total differential acts on elements in C_{p, q}Cp,qC_{p, q}Cp,q​ by \partial (x) = d(x) + (-1)^q \delta (x),∂(x)=d(x)+(−1)qδ(x),\partial (x) = d(x) + (-1)^q \delta (x),∂(x)=d(x)+(−1)qδ(x), where dddd is the vertical map, and \deltaδ\deltaδ the horizontal map. The sign here is to ensure that \partial ^2 = 0∂2=0\partial ^2 = 0∂2=0.

Given a bicomplex C_{ \bullet , \bullet }C∙,∙C_{ \bullet , \bullet }C∙,∙​, we can collapse it into a chain complex in two ways. In either way, C_{p, q}Cp,qC_{p, q}Cp,q​ is contained in the total complex at degree (m+n)(m+n)(m+n)(m+n). We can use the direct sum to combine them: \operatorname {Tot} ^ \oplus (C)_n = \bigoplus _{n = p+q} C_{p, q},Tot⁡⊕(C)n=⨁n=p+qCp,q,\operatorname {Tot} ^ \oplus (C)_n = \bigoplus _{n = p+q} C_{p, q},Tot⊕(C)n​=n=p+q⨁​Cp,q​, or the direct product: \operatorname {Tot} ^ \Pi (C)_n = \prod _{n=p+q} C_{p,q}.Tot⁡Π(C)n=∏n=p+qCp,q.\operatorname {Tot} ^ \Pi (C)_n = \prod _{n=p+q} C_{p,q}.TotΠ(C)n​=n=p+q∏​Cp,q​.

The total differential acts on elements in C_{p, q}Cp,qC_{p, q}Cp,q​ by \partial (x) = d(x) + (-1)^q \delta (x),∂(x)=d(x)+(−1)qδ(x),\partial (x) = d(x) + (-1)^q \delta (x),∂(x)=d(x)+(−1)qδ(x), where dddd is the vertical map, and \deltaδ\deltaδ the horizontal map. The sign here is to ensure that \partial ^2 = 0∂2=0\partial ^2 = 0∂2=0.
